content: The Act is titled the "United States-India Nuclear Cooperation Approval and Nonproliferation Enhancement Act" and includes sections on the approval of the agreement for peaceful uses of nuclear energy between the two countries, as well as strengthening nonproliferation laws related to peaceful nuclear cooperation. Sec. 201-205 outline procedures for subsequent reprocessing arrangements, initiatives for peaceful nuclear cooperation agreements, actions for resuming cooperation, US policy at the Nuclear Suppliers Group, and conforming amendments. Definitions in the Act include the United States-India Agreement for Cooperation on Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The appropriate congressional committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate are responsible for approving the United States-India Agreement for Cooperation on Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy. The President must certify to Congress that the Agreement's implementation is consistent with the United States' obligations under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons before exchanging diplomatic notes. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty was signed in 1968 and entered into force in 1970. The Agreement does not encourage India to develop nuclear weapons. The Agreement does not override the legal requirements of the Henry J. Hyde United States-India Peaceful Atomic Energy Cooperation Act of 2006 or the Atomic Energy Act of 1954. Congress urges India to sign an Additional Protocol with the IAEA and implement safeguards agreements. Licenses may be issued by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission may issue licenses for transfers under the Agreement only after the President certifies to Congress that the Safeguards Agreement with India has entered into force and India has filed a declaration of facilities consistent with the separation plan presented in 2006. Hyde United States-India Peaceful Atomic Energy Cooperation Act of 2006 is amended to include reporting to Congress on any inconsistencies between notifications by the Government of India and the separation plan presented in 2006. Hyde United States-India Peaceful Atomic Energy Cooperation Act of 2006 requires reporting to Congress on any inconsistencies between notifications by the Government of India and the separation plan presented in 2006, particularly regarding the United States-India Agreement for Cooperation on Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy. The amendment to SEC. 105 of the Henry J. Hyde United States-India Peaceful Atomic Energy Cooperation Act of 2006 mandates reporting to Congress on the provision of sensitive nuclear technology to India and facilities notified under the Agreement. The reporting to Congress includes agreed safeguards, research and development, civil nuclear cooperation activities, strategic reserve of nuclear fuel development, and political commitments fulfillment under the US-India nuclear cooperation Agreement. The reporting to Congress includes fulfilling political commitments made in the US-India nuclear cooperation Agreement, negotiations under Article 6(iii.), and transfers beyond India's jurisdiction under Article 7(2). The reporting to Congress includes an analysis of instances where the US or India requested consultations on compliance with Article 7(1) of the Agreement, any additional matters under Article 13(2) that were subject to consultations, and whether these matters were resolved. It also includes a statement on expected consultations under Article 16(5) and any enrichment activities under Article 6. TITLE II--STRENGTHENING UNITED STATES NONPROLIFERATION LAW RELATING TO PEACEFUL NUCLEAR COOPERATION. SEC. 201. PROCEDURES REGARDING A SUBSEQUENT ARRANGEMENT ON REPROCESSING. Notwithstanding the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, any proposed subsequent arrangement on reprocessing must meet specific requirements before taking effect. These requirements include the President submitting a report to congressional committees detailing the reasons for the arrangement, its text, and a certification of efforts to ensure other nations follow similar guidelines. Efforts are made to ensure that any nation allowing India to reprocess nuclear material transferred by them must do so under similar arrangements. A 30-day period of continuous session is required after the report is transmitted. A subsequent arrangement on reprocessing will not take effect if Congress adopts a joint resolution of disapproval within the specified time. In subsection (b)(2), Congress enacts a joint resolution stating opposition to any subsequent arrangement for reprocessing nuclear material. The President must inform relevant congressional committees of any initiatives or negotiations for new or amended peaceful nuclear cooperation agreements. SEC. 203 amends the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 by changing the requirement for congressional resolution to a joint resolution. SEC. 204 requires the President to certify the US policy to strengthen the international nuclear nonproliferation regime before exchanging diplomatic notes with the Nuclear Suppliers Group.
